choices.text: Allosteric effectors bind allosteric enzymes at their active sites
Allosteric control with negative feedback is found in many metabolic pathways

questions.text: While studying the regulation of metabolic pathways, a medical student comes across the concept of allosteric control, particularly its role in enzyme activity. Allosteric enzymes have unique characteristics that differentiate them from other enzymes. Which of the following statements accurately describes a property of allosteric enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Allosteric control with negative feedback is found in many metabolic pathways

 

Explanation:

 

Allosteric control with negative feedback is indeed a key regulatory mechanism in many metabolic pathways, making option D correct. In negative feedback allosteric regulation, the end product of a metabolic pathway inhibits an enzyme at an earlier step in the pathway, effectively shutting down production when sufficient product has accumulated. Classic examples include:

  1. Inhibition of phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) by ATP in glycolysis
  2. Inhibition of aspartate transcarbamoylase (ATCase) by CTP in pyrimidine synthesis

 

Other options: 

 

 

Option A. Allosteric effectors bind allosteric enzymes at their active sites: This statement is incorrect. By definition, allosteric effectors bind to sites distinct from the active site, called allosteric sites. The term "allosteric" comes from "allo" (other) and "steric" (space or structure), referring to binding at a site other than the active site. When an allosteric effector binds, it induces a conformational change that alters the activity of the enzyme.

 

Option B. Allosteric enzymes possess secondary structure: This statement is correct but not distinctive. All proteins, including enzymes (allosteric or not), possess secondary structure elements such as alpha helices and beta sheets. This is not a unique characteristic of allosteric enzymes.

 

Option C. Allosteric control is irreversible: This is incorrect. Allosteric regulation is typically reversible, allowing for rapid adaptation to changing cellular conditions. When the concentration of the allosteric effector decreases, the enzyme can return to its original conformation and activity state.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Allosteric enzymes are typically oligomeric proteins with multiple subunits that exhibit cooperativity and sigmoidal kinetics rather than the hyperbolic kinetics of Michaelis-Menten enzymes. Their activity can be modulated by effectors binding at sites distinct from the active site, causing conformational changes that alter the enzyme's catalytic efficiency. This provides a rapid, reversible mechanism for regulating metabolic pathways in response to changing cellular needs, with negative feedback being one of the most common control mechanisms in metabolism.

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 62.

questions.text: Which of the following examples best illustrates the concept of enzyme induction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ALA synthase by barbiturates

 

Option A.

 

  • Induction is effected through the process of derepression. 
  • The inducer will relieve the repression on the operator site and will remove the block on the biosynthesis of the enzyme molecules.
  • E.g: Induction of lactose-utilizing enzymes in the bacteria when the media contains lactose in the absence of glucose.
  • Tryptophan pyrrolase and transaminases are induced by glucocorticoids.
  • Glucokinase is induced by insulin.
  • ALA synthase is induced by barbiturates.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Succinate dehydrogenase by malonate: e.g of competitive inhibition.

 

Option C. Cytochromes by cyanide: e.g of Non-competitive inhibition.

 

Option D. ALA synthase by heme: e.g: of Repression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barbiturates can induce the synthesis of ALA synthase, an enzyme involved in the heme synthesis pathway, by increasing the transcription of its gene. This is an example of enzyme induction where the presence of a compound (barbiturates) increases the production and activity of an enzyme.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 64.

choices.text: Active site is the allosteric site in enzymes
All the allosteric enzymes possess positive cooperativity
Allosteric inhibitor is not a structural analogue
Activity of allosteric enzymes is described by Michaelis-Menten equation

questions.text: During a biochemistry seminar, the discussion turns to the regulation of metabolic pathways by allosteric enzymes. These enzymes are unique because their activity can be modulated by molecules binding to sites other than the active site. Which of the following statements correctly describes a feature of allosteric enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Allosteric inhibitor is not a structural analogue

 

Option C.

 

Allosteric enzymes are regulated by molecules that bind to specific sites called allosteric sites, which are distinct from the active site where substrate molecules bind. The binding of allosteric regulators to these sites can induce conformational changes in the enzyme, either enhancing or inhibiting its activity. Unlike competitive inhibitors that often mimic the substrate's structure to bind the active site, allosteric inhibitors can have vastly different structures from the substrate since they do not compete for the active site.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Allosteric enzyme has one catalytic site to which the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds.

 

Option B. In most cases, a combination of both positive and negative cooperativity is observed, resulting in a sigmoid shaped curve.

 

Option D. Not by Michaelis-Menten equation. Allosteric enzymes often display sigmoidal kinetics due to their regulatory mechanisms, which are not captured by the Michaelis-Menten model that assumes a hyperbolic relationship between enzyme activity and substrate concentration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Salient features of allosteric inhibition:

 

  1. The inhibitor is not a substrate analog.
  2. It is partially reversible, when excess substrate is added.
  3. Km is usually increased and Vmax is reduced.
  4. The effect of an allosteric modifier is maximum at or near substrate concentration equivalent to Km.
  5. When an inhibitor binds to the allosteric site, the configuration of the catalytic site is modified such that the substrate cannot bind properly.
  6. Most allosteric enzymes possess quaternary structure and are made up of subunits, e.g. Aspartate transcarbamoylase: 6 subunits and pyruvate kinase: 4 subunits.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 62,63.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the enzyme inhibition shown in the picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. D.   Allosteric inhibition

 

Option D.

 

  • Allosteric enzymes have one catalytic site for the substrate to bind and another separate allosteric site for the modifier to bind.
  • Allosteric and substrate binding sites may or may not be physically adjacent.
  • The binding of the regulatory molecule can either enhance the activity of the enzyme (allosteric activation) or inhibit the activity of the enzyme (allosteric inhibition).
  • The binding of substrate to one of the subunits of the enzyme may enhance substrate binding by other subunits.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Competitive inhibition: This would typically result in an increase in the apparent Km (decreased affinity) without affecting Vmax, and the graph would show a Michaelis-Menten curve, not a sigmoidal one.

 

Option B. Non-competitive inhibition: This generally results in a decreased Vmax while the Km remains unchanged; the graph would still follow Michaelis-Menten kinetics.

 

Option C. Uncompetitive inhibition: This occurs when an inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, leading to a parallel decrease in both Km and Vmax, which is not shown in the provided graph.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Salient features of allosteric inhibition:

 

  1. The inhibitor is not a substrate analog.
  2. It is partially reversible, when excess substrate is added.
  3. Km is increased and Vmax is reduced.
  4. The effect of allosteric modifier is maximum at or near substrate concentration equivalent to Km.
  5. Most allosteric enzymes possess quaternary structure. They are made up of subunits, e.g. Aspartate transcarbamoylase has 6 subunits and pyruvate kinase has 4 subunits.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 62.

questions.text: A team of endocrinologists is conducting a study on the regulation of fat metabolism by various hormones. Their research focuses on the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) in adipose tissue, a crucial enzyme in the mobilization of stored fats. Through their investigations, they aim to determine which hormone does not stimulate an increase in HSL activity. Which hormone is NOT associated with an increase in the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase in adipose tissue?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Insulin

 

Option D:

 

Insulin Favours Lipogenesis

 

  • Insulin increases the uptake of glucose by adipocytes and increases the activity of pyruvate dehydrogenase, acetyl CoA carboxylase and glycerol phosphate acyl transferase
  • But Insulin suppresses hormone sensitive lipase.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Adrenaline: This hormone activates hormone-sensitive lipase via the cAMP signaling pathway, leading to increased lipolysis.

 

Option B: Growth hormone: Growth hormone can stimulate lipolysis in adipose tissue, partly by increasing HSL activity.

 

Option C: Corticosteroids: Corticosteroids can also promote lipolysis, although their effect may be more complex and context-dependent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Insulin is known to inhibit the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) in adipose tissue.
  • HSL plays a key role in the hydrolysis of stored triglycerides into free fatty acids and glycerol, a process that is suppressed by insulin.
  • Insulin promotes fat storage by inhibiting lipolysis, in contrast to hormones like adrenaline, growth hormone, and corticosteroids, which stimulate HSL activity and promote fat breakdown.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 159

choices.text: Decreased connecting peptide in the blood

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with symptoms suggestive of an endocrine disorder and, after a series of diagnostic evaluations, is diagnosed with insulinoma, a rare neuroendocrine tumor primarily affecting the pancreas. Considering the pathophysiology of insulinoma, which of the following is a characteristic feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased glucose in the blood

 

Option B:

                            

  • Insulinomas have constant production of insulin (C-peptide) by the tumour cells. Insulin being an anabolic hormone, causes gain in body weight.
  • Such increase in insulin, favours the glucose uptake by tissues such as muscle and adipose that have insulin-dependent glucose transporters leading to hypoglycaemia.
  • The hypoglycemia is therefore insufficient to suppress insulin production and secretion.
  • Therefore Insulinomas are characterized by increased blood insulin and decreased blood glucose.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.  Decreased body weight: Insulin, an anabolic hormone causes gain in body weight.

 

Option C. Decreased connecting peptide in the blood: Insulinomas results in increased production of insulin (C-peptide).

 

Option D.  Decreased insulin in the blood: Increase in insulin levels due to constant production by the tumour cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulinomas are pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors that autonomously secrete insulin, leading to inappropriate insulin levels irrespective of blood glucose concentrations. This excessive insulin secretion results in recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia, which is a hallmark feature of insulinoma. Hypoglycemia can manifest as neuroglycopenic symptoms (confusion, blurred vision, fainting) and adrenergic symptoms (sweating, palpitations, hunger).

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 331, Lippincott 6/ed: p 319-320

choices.text: Extremes of pH can lead to denaturation of the enzyme
Maximal enzyme activity is achieved at same pH for all the enzymes
Pepsin is denatured by acidic pH
{E} and {S} must have chemical groups in an ionized form to interact

questions.text: Pick up the true statement regarding pH of enzyme
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extremes of pH can lead to denaturation of the enzyme

 

Option A.

 

Effect of pH on the ionization of the active site:

 

  • The concentration of protons (H+) affects reaction velocity in many ways.
  • First, the catalytic process usually requires that the enzyme and substrate have specific chemical groups in either an ionized or unionized state to interact.
  • For example, catalytic activity may require that an amino group of the enzyme be in the protonated form (–NH3+).

 

 

  • At alkaline pH, this group is deprotonated, and the rate of the reaction then declines.
  • Effect of pH on enzyme denaturation:
  • Extremes of pH can lead to denaturation of the enzyme, because the structure of the catalytically active protein molecule depends on the ionic character of the amino acid side chains.
  • Variable pH optimum:
  • The pH at which maximal enzyme activity is achieved is different for different enzymes and it reflects the [H+] at which the enzyme functions in the body.
  • E.g: Pepsin, a digestive enzyme, is maximally active at pH 2, whereas other enzymes which work at neutral pH are denatured by such an acidic environment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The pH at which maximal enzyme activity is achieved is different for different enzymes.

 

Option C. Pepsin, a digestive enzyme is maximally active at pH 2.

 

Option D. The catalytic process requires enzymes and substrates to have specific chemical groups in either an ionized or unionized state to interact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enzymes function optimally within specific pH ranges, and extreme pH levels can cause denaturation, affecting their structure and activity. Different enzymes have distinct optimal pH values, reflecting their diverse roles and environments.

 

Ref: Lippincott 6/e: p 57, 58.

questions.text: A medical researcher is studying the efficiency of metabolic pathways and the role of multi-enzyme complexes in facilitating these processes. They focus on how these complexes streamline biochemical reactions to enhance cellular efficiency. Which of the following is an example of such a multi-enzyme complex that plays a pivotal role in metabolic pathways?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Both a and b

 

Option C.

 

Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase and Fatty acid synthase are both multi-enzyme complexes. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase is involved in the citric acid cycle, catalyzing the conversion of alpha-ketoglutarate to succinyl-CoA, while Fatty acid synthase is central to fatty acid biosynthesis, facilitating the formation of long-chain fatty acids from acetyl-CoA and malonyl-CoA. These complexes enhance the efficiency of metabolic pathways by closely associating multiple enzymatic activities, allowing for direct substrate channeling and regulation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: While this is a multi-enzyme complex, selecting this option ignores the role of Fatty acid synthase, another critical multi-enzyme complex.

 

Option B. Fatty acid synthase: Similar to option a, choosing this option alone overlooks the importance of Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase as a multi-enzyme complex in metabolism.

 

Option D. Only a: This option inaccurately suggests that only Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase is a multi-enzyme complex, disregarding the role of Fatty acid synthase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multi-enzyme Complexes

 

  • Generally the rate of reaction of enzymes is limited by the rate at which substrate molecules diffuse through solution and reach the active site of the enzyme.
  • In a series of reactions, the product of the first enzyme diffuses into the surrounding medium, later reaches the second enzyme, which may hinder the smooth and efficient work of the enzymes in a metabolic pathway.
  • This can be overcome by a multi-enzyme complex, so that the product of the first reaction is immediately transferred to the second enzyme and so on. E.g are:
  1. Fatty acid synthase
  2. Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex
  3. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  4. Glycine cleavage system
  5. Pyruvate carboxylase
  6. Pyrimidine nucleotide synthesis.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 66.

questions.text: In an investigation on the regulation of metabolic pathways through phosphorylation and dephosphorylation, a researcher studies the effect of these post-translational modifications on various enzymes. One particular focus is on enzymes whose catalytic activity is diminished upon dephosphorylation. Which enzyme listed below has its activity reduced through dephosphorylation?
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Glycogen Phosphorylase

 

Glycogen phosphorylase is the correct answer because its activity is indeed reduced through dephosphorylation. This enzyme catalyzes the breakdown of glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate, which is a key process in glycogenolysis.

 

Glycogen phosphorylase exists in two forms:

  • Phosphorylase a: The phosphorylated, active form
  • Phosphorylase b: The dephosphorylated, less active form

 

When glycogen phosphorylase is phosphorylated by phosphorylase kinase, it becomes highly active (phosphorylase a). Conversely, when it is dephosphorylated by protein phosphatase-1, its activity is significantly reduced (phosphorylase b). 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. HMG CoA reductase This is incorrect. HMG CoA reductase, the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol biosynthesis, shows the opposite behavior. It is inactivated by phosphorylation and activated by dephosphorylation. 

 

Option C. Pyruvate Dehydrogenase This is incorrect. Pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH), which converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA linking glycolysis to the TCA cycle, is actually activated by dephosphorylation. PDH is inactivated when phosphorylated by PDH kinase and activated when dephosphorylated by PDH phosphatase.

 

Option D. Phosphofructokinase This is incorrect. Phosphofructokinase (PFK), a key regulatory enzyme in glycolysis is activated by dephosphorylation.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

  1. Understand how phosphorylation and dephosphorylation serve as key regulatory mechanisms for enzyme activity in metabolic pathways.
  2. Differentiate between enzymes that are activated versus those that are inactivated by phosphorylation.
  3. Recognize the specific regulation pattern of glycogen phosphorylase and its role in glycogen metabolism:
    • Phosphorylation activation
    • Dephosphorylation inactivation
  4. Identify the opposite regulation pattern in enzymes like HMG CoA reductase and pyruvate dehydrogenase:
    • Phosphorylation inactivation
    • Dephosphorylation activation

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p91.

questions.text: In a discussion on the regulatory mechanisms of enzyme activity, a molecular biologist examines various types of covalent modifications. While most covalent modifications directly influence enzyme activity, one of the listed modifications typically serves other functions rather than directly regulating enzymatic activity. Which of the following covalent modifications is not primarily involved in regulating enzyme activity?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Glycosylation.

 

Option D.

 

Glycosylation, the addition of carbohydrate groups to proteins, is typically involved in protein folding, stability, and cell signalling rather than the direct regulation of enzyme activity. While glycosylation can influence protein function, it is not commonly used as a regulatory mechanism for enzyme activity in the same way as phosphorylation, acetylation, or ADP ribosylation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Phosphorylation: This is a common regulatory mechanism that can activate or deactivate enzymes by adding a phosphate group, often altering the enzyme's structure and activity.

 

Option B. Acetylation: The addition of an acetyl group to proteins, including enzymes, can affect their activity, stability, and interactions with other molecules.

 

Option C. ADP Ribosylation: This modification involves adding ADP-ribose units to proteins and can significantly affect enzyme function and cell signalling pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reversible covalent modifications

 

  • Phosphorylation, Dephosphorylation
  • ADP Ribosylation
  • Methylation
  • Acetylation.

 

Irreversible Covalent Modification

 

  • Zymogen activation/ Partial Proteolysis.

 

Ref: Harper 29/e p89

questions.text: In research examining various regulatory mechanisms of enzyme function, several methods are discussed that directly influence enzyme activity through structural modifications. One method mentioned, however, primarily affects the availability of the enzyme rather than its intrinsic activity. Which of the following is primarily associated with altering enzyme levels rather than directly modifying enzyme activity?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Induction

 

Option C.

 

Induction refers to the process by which the expression of enzymes is increased, often in response to specific stimuli or environmental conditions. While induction leads to an increased quantity of enzyme, it does not directly modify the activity of existing enzyme molecules, unlike the other options which involve covalent modifications that can alter enzyme function.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Methylation: The addition of methyl groups to enzymes can directly alter their activity, specificity, or interactions with other molecules.

 

Option B. Acetylation: Similar to methylation, acetylation involves the addition of acetyl groups to enzymes, affecting their activity and function.

 

Option D. Phosphorylation: This is a common regulatory mechanism where the addition of phosphate groups to enzymes can activate or inhibit their activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Regulation of Enzymes can be classified as:

 

  1. Regulation of Enzyme Quality (Intrinsic Catalytic Efficiency)
    • Allosteric Regulation
    • Covalent modification
    • Covalent modification
    • Phosphorylation/dephosphorylation [Most Common covalent modification]
    • Methylation
    • Adenylation
    • ADP ribosylation
    • Acetylation
  2. Regulation of enzyme quantity
    • Control of Enzyme Synthesis by Induction and Repression of their respective gene expression
    • Control of Enzyme Degradation: Enzymes are degraded by Ubiquitin-Proteasome pathway.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p89, 90.

questions.text: In a discussion on metabolic pathways, a medical instructor emphasizes the importance of understanding how gluconeogenesis is regulated within the cell. One aspect under consideration is the spatial organization of the enzymes involved in this pathway. Is the regulation of gluconeogenesis influenced by the compartmentalization of its enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. True

 

Explanation

 

  • The activity of enzymes catalyzing the different steps in a metabolic pathway is regulated by compartmentalization of enzymes.
  • Few enzymes of the pathway may be located in mitochondria and other few enzymes of the same pathway are in cytoplasmic.
  • E.g: Heme synthesis, urea cycle and gluconeogenesis.
  • The intermediates of the pathways are shuttled across the mitochondrial membrane for this purpose which provides a point where controls can be exerted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gluconeogenesis is indeed regulated by the compartmentalization of its enzymes. This spatial organization allows for efficient control of the pathway, ensuring that enzymes necessary for gluconeogenesis are localized in specific areas of the cell, primarily within the mitochondria and cytoplasm of liver cells. This compartmentalization facilitates the regulation of enzyme activity and substrate availability, crucial for the maintenance of blood glucose levels, especially during fasting.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e:  p 65.

questions.text: In a clinical discussion on metabolic regulation, a topic of interest is the mechanism of feedback inhibition in enzymatic pathways. This regulatory process is crucial for maintaining homeostasis within the body. What primarily influences feedback inhibition of enzymes in metabolic pathways?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. End product 

 

Option C.

 

Feedback inhibition: The activity of the enzyme is inhibited by the final product of the reaction/ pathway.

 

  1. E.g: Inhibition of hexokinase by glucose-6-phosphate.

 

        Glucose + ATP → Glucose-6-phosphate + ADP

 

  1. Carbamoyl phosphate + Aspartate   ----→ Carbamoyl aspartate + Pi       

                                 Aspartate transcarbamoylase

 (CTP, the end product will allosterically inhibit aspartate transcarbamoylase)

 

  1. Succinyl CoA + Glycine ---------------------→ delta aminolevulinic acid (ALA)

       (The end product, heme will allosterically inhibit the ALA synthase).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Enzyme: While enzymes are crucial for catalyzing reactions, they are not the primary initiators of feedback inhibition. Instead, their activity can be modulated by various factors, including the end product of the pathway they are part of.

 

Option B. External factors: External factors such as temperature, pH, and the presence of inhibitors or activators can affect enzyme activity, but they are not typically involved in feedback inhibition, which is an intrinsic regulatory mechanism of the metabolic pathway.

 

Option D. Substrate: The substrate is necessary for the enzyme to act upon, but the accumulation of substrate does not typically lead to feedback inhibition. Instead, feedback inhibition is usually triggered by the accumulation of the end product of the pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Feedback inhibition occurs when the end product of a metabolic pathway accumulates to a level that inhibits the activity of an enzyme involved in an earlier step of the pathway. This mechanism prevents overproduction of the end product and conserves cellular resources.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 64.

questions.text: During a molecular biology lecture on gene expression regulation, the professor emphasizes mechanisms that operate at the gene level to control enzyme synthesis and activity. One of the discussed mechanisms involves the downregulation or inhibition of enzyme synthesis in response to specific signals. Which of the following phenomena specifically acts at the gene level to regulate enzyme synthesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Repression

 

Option B.

 

  • Repressor acts at the gene level and the effect is noticeable only after a lag period of hours or days.

 

 

  • The number of enzyme molecules is reduced in the presence of repressor molecule.
  • E.g: ALA synthase by heme.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Allosteric activation: This involves the binding of an effector molecule to an enzyme at a site other than the active site, leading to a conformational change that affects enzyme activity, not gene expression.

 

Option C. Cooperative activation: This refers to the phenomenon where the binding of a substrate or activator to one active site on a multi-subunit enzyme enhances the activity at other active sites, not directly related to gene expression.

 

Option D. Feed forward activation: This is a metabolic control mechanism where an enzyme is activated by an intermediate that precedes the enzyme in the pathway, not a gene-level regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Repression, in the context of gene expression, refers to a regulatory mechanism where gene expression is decreased in response to a specific signal, often involving the binding of repressor proteins to DNA sequences near the genes being regulated. This decreases the transcription of those genes, leading to reduced synthesis of the corresponding enzymes.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 64.

questions.text: As we Increase Temperature initially velocity of an enzymatic reaction increases after a particular temperature velocity of enzymatic reaction decreases. Is this statement true or false?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. True

 

Option A:

 

The velocity of the reaction increases with increase in temperature peak velocity is reached Further elevation of the temperature decrease in reaction velocity as a result of temperature induced denaturation of the enzyme.

 

The optimum temperature for most human enzymes is between 35C and 40C, after which human enzymes start to denature.

 

But thermophilic bacteria found in the hot springs have optimum temperatures of 70C.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Denaturation disrupts the enzyme's three-dimensional structure, essential for its catalytic activity, ultimately resulting in a decrease in reaction velocity.

 

Ref: Lippincott 6/e: p 57

questions.text: MATCH the following enzymes and its allosteric inhibitor:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

Explanation:

 

  • Phosphofructokinase, a key regulatory enzyme in glycolysis, is allosterically inhibited by ATP, reflecting the cell's energy status.
  • ALA synthase, involved in the synthesis of porphyrins, is inhibited by heme, its end product, to regulate heme synthesis.
  • Aspartate transcarbamoylase, a crucial enzyme in pyrimidine nucleotide synthesis, is inhibited by CTP, demonstrating feedback inhibition.
  • HMG CoA-reductase, pivotal in cholesterol biosynthesis, is regulated through feedback inhibition by cholesterol.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 63.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds does not typically act as a second messenger in neuronal signal transduction pathways?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) None

 

OPTION D:

 

Explanation:

 

Cyclic AMP – Group IA and Calcium ions and PIP2 - Group IC: all 3 act as second messengers.

 

Option A. Cyclic AMP (cAMP): Widely recognized as a second messenger in various cell types, including neurons, where it mediates responses to neurotransmitters and hormones.

 

Option B. Calcium ions (Ca2+): Serve as pivotal second messengers in neuronal signaling, involved in processes such as neurotransmitter release, neuron excitability, and gene expression.

 

Option C. PIP2 (Phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate): It is a precursor for the generation of IP3 (Inositol trisphosphate) and DAG (Diacylglycerol) upon hydrolysis by phospholipase C, both of which act as second messengers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 668.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones does NOT primarily act at the level of transcription?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Calcitonin

 

Option C:

 

Calcitonin primarily acts to lower blood calcium levels by inhibiting osteoclast activity in the bones and increasing calcium excretion in the kidneys. Unlike cortisol, calcitriol, and androgens, which can directly influence gene transcription by interacting with intracellular receptors that then act as transcription factors, calcitonin works through a cell surface receptor, leading to effects that do not directly involve changes in gene transcription.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cortisol: Cortisol, a glucocorticoid hormone produced by the adrenal cortex, passes through cell membranes and binds to glucocorticoid receptors inside the cell. The hormone-receptor complex then translocate to the nucleus, where it can act as a transcription factor, influencing the expression of genes involved in various metabolic processes, immune response, and stress responses.

 

Option B. Calcitriol: Calcitriol, the active form of vitamin D, exerts its effects by entering cells and binding to the vitamin D receptor (VDR), which then forms a complex that functions as a transcription factor. This complex can bind to vitamin D response elements (VDREs) on DNA, regulating the transcription of genes involved in calcium and phosphate homeostasis, among other functions.

 

Option D. Androgen: Androgens, such as testosterone, exert many of their physiological effects by entering cells and binding to the androgen receptor. This complex then migrates to the nucleus, where it can bind to specific DNA sequences and regulate the transcription of genes responsible for the development and maintenance of male characteristics, as well as other metabolic processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nuclear Receptors have a DNA binding domain (DBD) in their middle region through which they bind the specific region of DNA, known as hormone response elements (HRE).

 

 

  • These receptors also have a ligand binding domain (LBD) at the carboxy terminal half.
  • A hinge region separates the DBD and LBD regions.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 654

choices.text: Inhibition of protein synthesis
Inhibition of a stimulatory G protein
Activation of a stimulatory G protein
Inhibition of an inhibitory G protein

questions.text: A family trip to the shore results in a 3-year-old boy consuming clams for dinner. Shortly thereafter, he exhibits symptoms of severe watery diarrhea, vomiting, and leg cramps. To identify the molecular basis of his disorder, which of the following mechanisms is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Activation of a stimulatory G protein

 

Option C:

 

 

 

  • The boy is suffering from cholera, caused by the bacterium vibrio cholera → produces a toxin → ADP-ribosylation a stimulatory G protein → permanent activation of the protein (Via inhibition of the intrinsic GTPase activity) → constant cAMP production, which in turn causes secretion of sodium and water into the lumen of the intestine, resulting in watery diarrhoea.
  • If not treated, it causes severe dehydration and death.
  • The IMAGE outlines the action of cholera toxin in intestinal epithelial cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Inhibition of protein synthesis: Certain toxins can inhibit protein synthesis, leading to cellular death and systemic symptoms, but this mechanism is more commonly associated with neurotoxins and does not typically result in the acute gastrointestinal symptoms described.

 

Option B. Inhibition of a stimulatory G protein: Inhibiting a stimulatory G protein would likely reduce cellular activity mediated by this pathway, contrary to the excessive fluid secretion observed in the boy's symptoms.

 

Option D. Inhibition of an inhibitory G protein: Inhibiting an inhibitory G protein could potentially lead to increased cellular activity, similar to activating a stimulatory G protein, but the most direct mechanism in this context is the activation of the stimulatory G protein itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The molecular basis for the acute gastrointestinal symptoms following the consumption of contaminated shellfish is most likely the activation of stimulatory G proteins in intestinal cells. This leads to increased cAMP levels, resulting in excessive fluid secretion and the observed symptoms of diarrhoea, vomiting, and cramps.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 668

choices.text: It is a dimer made of non-identical subunits
Two subunits are in parallel direction
Intermediates of the reaction can’t interact with enzymes
One gene codes for all the enzymes

questions.text: Which one of the following statement is correct regarding fatty acid synthase complex in mammals:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) One gene codes for all the enzymes

 

Option D:

 

  • FAS complex is a homodimer with two identical polypeptide monomers or subunits
  • It consists of 6 enzymes and a acyl carrier protein (contains Pantothenic acid )
  • Intermediates of the reaction can interact with the active sites of the enzymes.
  • One gene codes all the enzymes; so, all the enzymes are formed in an equimolecular concentration.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: It is a dimer with non-identical subunits: Is a homodimer with two identical polypeptide monomers.

 

Option B: Two subunits are in parallel direction: Antiparallel direction (Head to tail)

 

Option C: Intermediates of the reaction can’t interact with enzymes: Intermediates can interact with the active sites of the enzymes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fatty acid synthase complex in mammals is a large, multifunctional enzyme complex. Each subunit of the dimeric complex contains all the enzymatic activities necessary for fatty acid synthesis. In mammals, a single gene codes for a polypeptide that has all the enzymatic activities required for the fatty acid synthesis cycle.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 233-234

questions.text: A group of researchers is exploring potential targets for the development of a new class of weight management drugs focused on inhibiting lipogenesis. In their discussions, they examine key regulatory enzymes within the fatty acid synthesis pathway. Which enzyme is recognized as the most crucial in regulating lipogenesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acetyl-CoA carboxylase

 

Option A:

 

Acetyl-CoA carboxylase plays a pivotal role in regulating lipogenesis. It catalyzes the conversion of acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA, the first committed step in fatty acid synthesis. This reaction is not only rate-limiting but also regulated by various nutritional and hormonal signals, making acetyl-CoA carboxylase a key point of control in lipogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Medium-chain acetyl-CoA dehydrogenase: This enzyme is involved in the β-oxidation of fatty acids, a catabolic process that breaks down fatty acids to produce energy, and is not directly involved in lipogenesis regulation.

 

Option C: Short chain enoyl reductase: This enzyme also participates in fatty acid β-oxidation, specifically in the reduction step, and does not regulate lipogenesis.

 

Option D: Long-chain enoyl hydratase: Similar to the other two enzymes mentioned, this enzyme functions in the β-oxidation pathway and is not a regulator of fatty acid synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetyl-CoA carboxylase catalyzes the first step of lipogenesis in which acetyl-CoA is linked to malonyl-CoA. It is the rate limiting and regulatory enzyme of fatty acid synthesis. It is activated by citrate and inhibited by palmitate.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 158

choices.text: A and R both are right, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A as well as R are right, and R is a correct explanation of A
A is right but R is a wrong statement
A and R both are wrong

questions.text:
Assertion (A): A patient suffering from cholera loses fluid rich in Na+, K+, Cl- in vomiting and diarrhoea.


Reasoning (R): Cholera toxin causes ADP ribosylation of Na+ Cl- antiport of the GIT mucosa.

 

Evaluate the connection between the assertion and the reasoning:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A is right, but R is a wrong statement.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Cholera toxin causes ADP ribosylation of adenylate cyclase resulting in excessive cAMP formation, which causes phosphorylation of chloride channels and loss of Cl- and Na+ in the intestinal fluid.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with cholera do lose significant amounts of fluids rich in Na+, K+, and Cl- due to the profuse vomiting and watery diarrhea characteristic of the disease.

 

Cholera toxin does not act on a Na+ Cl- antiport. Instead, it causes ADP ribosylation of the Gs alpha subunit of the adenylate cyclase system in intestinal epithelial cells, leading to increased cAMP levels, which in turn cause the efflux of Cl- and inhibit the absorption of Na+, resulting in water loss into the intestinal lumen.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 87, 218,250,491,522.

questions.text: In a biotechnology company focused on metabolic engineering, a team is analyzing the fatty acid synthase (FAS) complex to identify potential targets for genetic modification to enhance biofuel production. During their review, they discuss the various enzymes that compose the FAS complex. They aim to clarify which enzyme listed is not a part of this complex. Which of the following enzymes is not contained within the fatty acid synthase complex?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acetyl CoA carboxylase

 

Option C:

 

Acetyl CoA carboxylase is not a part of the fatty acid synthase complex. Instead, it functions upstream of fatty acid synthesis, catalyzing the conversion of acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA, which is then used as a substrate by the fatty acid synthase complex. This enzyme is crucial for the regulation of fatty acid synthesis but operates independently of the FAS complex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Enoyl Reductase: This enzyme is a component of the FAS complex and is involved in the reduction of the double bond between carbon atoms in the fatty acid chain.

 

Option B: Ketoacyl reductase: Also part of the FAS complex, this enzyme reduces keto groups to hydroxyl groups during fatty acid elongation.

 

Option D: Dehydratase: This enzyme, found within the FAS complex, removes water from hydroxyl groups to create a double bond, facilitating the reduction steps that extend the fatty acid chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Six enzyme activities of Fatty acid synthase complex are:

 

  • Ketoacyl Synthase
  • Malonyl-Acetyl Transacylase
  • Hydratase
  • Enoyl Reductase
  • Ketoacyl Reductase
  • Thioesterase (Deacylase)

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 156-158.
